ratings.comment: Very relaxed, which is good or bad depending on you. Regularly posted assignments and lectures late or not at all, didn't grade until the end of the semester and was very hard to get in touch with. But, she graded very easy, offered EC, was understanding if you had any logistical issues, and to be fair the content was very good and I learned a lot

Attendance was mandatory but she ended up cancelling about 6 classes herself. The slides& lectures were kind of a mess and had a lot of typos. The content itself was interesting and it was not too hard of a class.

She was a very kind and chill instructor but lectures were lowkey a mess and you could tell she didn't want to be there. She ended up cancelling like two full weeks of class but attendance at lecture was somehow still mandatory for us.

Professor Anderson was the ONLY professor to take my disability accommodations seriously and reach out to check in on me. She is unbelievably kind and gives great feedback. You learn a ton in the course, but the assessments aren't designed to trip you up or trick you. By far my favorite course that semester. You are an icon, Prof Anderson!

Prof Anderson was great! If you skim through the readings and pay attention to her lectures, you should be set for an A. The "exams" are three essays with very interesting and creative topics (nothing boring). She puts students mental health first, and she offered 48-hour extension on assignments.

Courts, Constitutionalism, and Human Rights is a good (but relatively boring) class. It's graded on three papers (graded VERY leniently), weekly completion assignments, and participation. Professor Anderson is knowledgable and accessible outside of class. Her slides are well-written, but she reads directly off them.
